abstract: Abstract We have studied vertical progression behaviour in Helix and its modification by the animals' encountering either quinine or water on a thread tied at the top of vertically-placed glass rods. There is both short and long term memory of the aversive (quinine) experience, as well as habituation of climbing in snails encountering an apparently neutral (water) stimulus. Some of the factors which appear to influence climbing latencies and acquisition and retention of the nature of the goal stimulus are: length of laboratory housing, humidity and nutritional and reproductive condition.
